overall_summary: The reasoning trajectory demonstrates a methodical approach to forecasting a 96-hour time series with clear daily seasonality and a short data history. The analyst identifies key patterns, evaluates multiple modeling techniques (SARIMA, Exponential Smoothing), but ultimately selects a simple averaging method due to data limitations. The approach prioritizes stability and interpretability over complex modeling, with thorough consideration of data characteristics and practical constraints.
common_data_patterns: Upward trend (increasing values over observed days)
Complete data (no missing values in the input segment)
Negative values during daytime, positive at night
key_insights: Limited data size (4 days) makes complex models like SARIMA over-parameterized and impractical
Hourly averaging effectively captures daily seasonality when historical cycles are consistent
Explicit trend modeling (e.g., linear regression per hour) is unreliable with only 4 data points per hour
Data completeness checks precede modeling decisions
Negative value handling requires additive (not multiplicative) seasonality approaches
complexity_analysis: Moderately complex: Combines pattern recognition, method evaluation, and practical simplification. Balances statistical considerations (seasonality/trend) with heuristic implementation due to data constraints.
